elements.title: Risks Associated with Acquisitions and Growth Investments

data.value: Investments and acquisitions may not yield expected results.
Expected in development and expansion.
Concern over sufficient revenue and potential losses.
Focus on acquiring strategic retail locations and complementary businesses.
Include management time diversion, integration challenges, and potential write-offs.
Intention to self-fund growth, but potential for dilutive equity and other financial impacts.
Challenges in integrating acquired businesses may lead to unforeseen expenses or failure in recognizing anticipated benefits.
Integration requires significant internal and external resources, potentially diverting management's attention from daily operations.
Employee uncertainty during integration processes may disrupt the Company's business.
Dependence on key personnel is critical; their retention and integration are essential for growth.
The success of the business hinges on efforts and effectiveness of executives like Chairman and CEO, Marshall Chesrown.
Loss of senior management or key employees may adversely impact the execution of the business plan.
Difficulty in retaining qualified personnel may hinder business growth.
Operating results are subject to fluctuations based on various internal and external economic factors.

elements.title: RumbleOn’s Solution — Creating the Future of Powersports

data.value: RumbleOn is creating a best-in-class experience in powersports by offering unmatched choice and selection.
RumbleOn's key initiatives focus on improving customer experience and expanding inventory.
Creating an end-to-end ownership experience with a focus on quality assurance, pricing, and after-sales service.
Positioned to acquire high-quality used vehicles, leveraging the Cash Offer Tool.
Focused on both new and used vehicle sales, with an emphasis on increasing used inventory sales.

elements.title: Development of the RideNow Powersports Brand

data.value: Development of 'RideNow Powersports' brand across retail locations.
Utilizing innovative technology to drive disruption in the powersports industry.
Leverage of technology and data for competitive advantage.

1. Proprietary supply chain pricing/distribution software; 2. Omnichannel and mobile-first web application; 3. Centralized CRM and inventory; 4. Dealer network support channels; 5. Data warehousing & reporting.
Optimized customer experiences through technology.

This table shows the movement of Restricted Stock Units (RSUs) over multiple periods. Starting with 443,843 units, the company granted and vested various amounts, with significant grants of 1.32M and 551K units. After accounting for vestings, forfeitures, and a cancellation of 440,000 units under LTIP, the final outstanding balance is 588,948 RSUs, all of which are expected to vest. The fair values varied from $13.26 to $37.48 per unit, with the final outstanding units valued at $31.92.

This table tracks stock options activity over three years (2020-2022). The number of outstanding options decreased from 2,751 to 2,380 due to forfeitures, with no new grants or exercises. The weighted average exercise price slightly decreased from $79.76 to $79.48, while the remaining contractual life decreased from 9.6 to 6.7 years. As of December 31, 2022, all 2,380 outstanding options were vested/exercisable. No intrinsic value was reported throughout the period.
RideNow: Approximately 30 locations, Harley-Davidson: Approximately 10 locations, BMW: Multiple locations, Indian: Multiple locations

$10,950 was reclassified as part of debt discount related to the Oaktree Credit Agreement.

data.key: Revenue recognition for pre-owned vehicle sales to consumers
data.value: Recognized at the agreed upon purchase price including any delivery charges, less an estimate for returns.
Returns can be initiated during the first three days after delivery.

elements.title: Definition and limitations of internal control over financial reporting

data.value: A company’s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements.

1. Maintenance of records to accurately reflect transactions and dispositions of assets. 2. Assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary for preparing financial statements. 3. Assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized use of the company’s assets.
Internal control may not prevent or detect misstatements, and controls may become inadequate over time due to changing conditions.

elements.title: Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements

data.value: The Company’s revenue consists primarily of pre-owned and wholesale vehicle sales as well as vehicle logistics and transportation services.

Cost of vehicle sales includes the cost to acquire vehicles and the reconditioning and transportation costs associated with preparing the vehicles for resale. Reconditioning costs include parts, labor, overhead costs, and other vehicle repair expenses directly attributable to specific vehicles. Transportation costs consist of costs incurred to transport the vehicles from the point of acquisition.

Selling, general and administrative expenses include costs and expenses for compensation and benefits, advertising to consumers and dealers, development and operating the product procurement and distribution system, managing the logistics system, and other corporate overhead expenses.
Advertising and marketing expenses were $31,327 and $14,425 for the years ended December 31, 2022 and 2021, respectively.

Stock-based compensation represents the cost related to stock-based awards granted to employees and non-employee directors. The Company measures stock-based compensation cost at the grant date and recognizes the cost on a straight-line basis.
The Company sponsors the RumbleOn, Inc. 401(k) Plan for eligible employees. Employer contributions to the plan, net of forfeitures, were approximately $192 and $722 for the years ended 2022 and 2021.

elements.title: RumbleOn: Forward-Looking Statements and Market Data

data.value: Contains forward-looking statements as defined in the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These statements are based on expectations and assumptions, subject to risks and uncertainties.
Readers are cautioned not to rely too much on these forward-looking statements due to potential discrepancies between actual results and the statements.
Some data is based on independent sources which may not be independently verified, and the accuracy of such data is uncertain.
RumbleOn is the first, largest publicly-traded, technology-based platform in the powersports industry.
RumbleOn is transforming customer experience in powersports through wide selection, great value, and easy transactions.
In 2022, announced winding down wholesale automotive business to complete in the first half of 2023.
Risks to the business and industry operations that could adversely affect financial condition.
Identified material weakness in internal control over financial reporting affecting accuracy of financial results.
Required compliance with Section 404 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act affecting internal controls.
Need for effective remediation of identified weaknesses for reliable financial reporting.
Significant indebtedness affecting business flexibility and increasing interest expense.
Exposure to variable interest rates affecting profitability.
Potential challenges in accessing capital markets due to internal or external factors.

elements.title: Risks Related to Economic Conditions and Inventory Management

data.value: The powersports industry is sensitive to unfavorable changes in general economic conditions, affecting demand for products and services.
Recent inflation increases can raise costs and reduce demand for powersports vehicles.
Higher interest rates can adversely influence vehicle affordability and borrowing capacity.
Risks related to inventory acquisition disruptions due to manufacturing slowdowns, chip shortages, and logistics challenges.
Inadequate financing or capital can restrict business growth and operational capabilities.

elements.title: Financial Performance Risks Related to Brand Development and Internet Competitiveness

data.value: If annual or quarterly operating results fall below expectations, share price could decline.
Failure to develop and maintain brands could harm reputation and customer trust.
Increased competition online for vehicles and services could adversely impact market share.
Inability to recover marketing costs through sufficient user traffic could affect financial health.
Dependency on search engines for traffic increases vulnerability to algorithm changes.
Complaints or negative publicity can diminish user confidence and affect business.

elements.title: Risk Factors Related to Service Disruptions and Third-Party Providers

data.value: A significant disruption in service on our website or of our mobile applications could damage our reputation and result in a loss of consumers.
Problems faced by any third-party web hosting providers we may utilize could adversely affect the experience of our consumers.
We may experience interruptions in one or more data feeds that we receive from third-party data providers.
Expansion into new product offerings may place us in competitive and regulatory environments with which we are unfamiliar.
Any shortfall in revenue could be material to our operating results.

elements.title: Third-Party Financing Dependencies and Market Competition

data.value: We rely on third-party financing providers to finance a portion of our customers’ vehicle purchases. Our revenue and results of operations are partially dependent on the actions of these third parties.

data.key: Adverse Effects of Third-Party Financing Disruptions
data.value: If one or more of these third-party providers cease to provide financing to our customers, or provide financing on less competitive terms, it could have a material adverse effect on our business.
We rely on third-party providers to supply extended protection products (EPP) to our customers.
Sales of powersports vehicles may be adversely impacted by increased supply or declining prices for new or pre-owned vehicles.
We rely on third parties to perform certain operating and administrative functions, which could lead to issues such as unfavorable pricing or service quality.
We participate in a highly competitive market with pressure from existing and new companies which may adversely affect our business.
Competitors, both new and existing, could complicate inventory acquisition, customer attraction, and sales at profitable prices.
Current and potential competitors may have significantly greater financial, technical, marketing resources, challenging ability to compete.
If competitors merge, it could adversely affect our competitive position.
Restrictive covenants in debt agreements may limit our growth initiatives and ability to respond to market conditions.
Defaulting on covenants could result in acceleration of debt and possible asset foreclosure.
Revenue may be influenced by seasonal buying patterns and economic cycles.

elements.title: Environmental Regulations and Data Privacy Risks

data.value: Climate change legislation or regulations restricting emission of greenhouse gases could result in increased operating costs and reduced demand for powersports vehicles.
The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency has adopted rules requiring reduction in greenhouse gas emissions from motor vehicles and permit reviews for large stationary sources.
New laws or regulations requiring significant increases in fuel economy may adversely affect vehicle demand and increase costs to reduce emissions.
Failure to protect personal information could lead to reputational damage and operational harm.
The company must comply with changing privacy laws globally which may conflict across jurisdictions.
Failure to protect intellectual property and proprietary information could harm business success.

elements.title: Impact of Economic Conditions and COVID-19 on Business Operations

data.value: Cash may be affected if financial institutions fail.
Pandemic has negatively impacted economic activity and consumer demand.
Supply constraints have affected vehicle inventory and pricing.
General economic conditions affect retail performance.
Retail powersports sales are cyclical and subject to downturns.
Revenue dependent on manufacturers' ability to produce desirable vehicles.
Changing consumer preferences can affect revenue and margins.

elements.title: Impact of Analyst Expectations and Proxy Contests on Stock Performance

data.value: The company's operating results failing to meet analyst expectations may lead to a decline in stock price.
The company does not intend to pay dividends on common stock and has never declared or paid cash dividends.
Earnings will be reinvested in business development and expansion.
The company is subject to reduced reporting requirements as a smaller reporting company, which may affect investment attractiveness.
Involvement of activist investors may lead to proxy contests, affecting business operations and financial condition.
A proposed contested election at the 2023 Annual Meeting of Stockholders could disrupt operations and lead to changes in control.
Provisions in Nevada law and company bylaws may discourage third-party acquisitions, impacting stock price.

elements.title: Policy For Approval Of Audit And Permitted Non-Audit Services

data.value: A committee that has adopted a policy requiring pre-approval of all audit and non-audit services by its independent registered public accounting firm.
To ensure that the provision of audit and non-audit services does not impair the firm's independence.
Audit services, audit related services, tax services, and other services.
Annual establishment of fee limits for various types of services.
Independent registered public accounting firm must provide backup information regarding the performance of provided services.
Grant Thornton and Forvis for the years ended December 31, 2022 and December 31, 2021, respectively.
The Chair of the Audit Committee is delegated the authority to pre-approve services up to a specified fee limit.
The Chair must report any pre-approved decisions at the next scheduled meeting of the Audit Committee.
